Award.AwardTitle: BSF:2012166:A Framework for Composite Techniques in Motion Planning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded as part of the United States-Israel Collaboration in Computer Science (USICCS) program. Through this program, NSF and the United States - Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF) jointly support collaborations among US-based researchers and Israel-based researchers. This project aims to design a framework for the integration of advanced foundational methods from computational geometry with effective sampling-based methods from motion planning. This will allow the practical use of these techniques in important applications and the development of useful educational experiences. Motion planning, in its basic form, corresponds to the problem of finding a collision-free path for a robot in a workspace cluttered with static obstacles. It is important for many application domains, such as manufacturing and warehouse management, product assembly, surgical planning, architectural design, graphical animation, computer games, and computational biology. The collaboration of the US and Israeli researchers will impact the application areas through the development of novel efficient tools based on sound theory for motion planning of complex systems. Furthermore, the availability of these tools can have an impact in educational efforts in the areas of algorithms, computational geometry and robotics.

Towards achieving these objectives, the investigators will implement and evaluate composite methods for motion planning, that lie at the intersection of computational geometry and sampling-based planning. In particular, the investigators will utilize foundational methods to compute compact motion planning representations that provide optimality guarantees, based in part on recent advances in summary of big data in other fields. The collaboration can also lead to advances in the area of multi-robot motion planning, by taking advantage of recent progress in combinatorial solvers and transferring these results in the continuous motion planning domain. Overall, the integrated framework will allow advances in geometry-based algorithms to be readily available to the motion planning community, especially in sampling entire low-dimensional manifolds of the configuration space instead of individual configurations, collision detection and space decomposition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This travel award fostered the collaboration between Prof. Dan
Halperin's research group at Tel Aviv University, a top international
group in computational geometry and algorithmic robotics, and
Prof. Kostas Bekris' research group at Rutgers University, which
specializes in robot motion planning, learning and perception.

As part of this project, multiple graduate students at Rutgers
University were trained on foundational properties of algorithmic
methods, which have real-world impact in robotics applications. They
had the opportunity to visit Tel Aviv University and directly interact
with researchers there.

A series of important outcomes resulted out of this collaboration
given the support of this project. In particular:

a) the research team showed how sampling-based methods can achieve
asymptotic optimality in the context of multi-robot problems in a way
that achieves scalability. The corresponding paper was awarded the
Best Paper Award at the 1st edition of the IEEE conference on
Multi-Robot Systems (MRS), which took place at the USC campus in 2017
and led to an invited journal article at the Autonomous Robot journal.

Furthermore, it was also shown that similar benefits can be achieved
in the context of controlling a humanoid robot that has two arms and
common degrees of freedom, such as a mobile base or a torso. This work
was presented at the IEEE Humanoids conference in 2017.

b) The Rutgers PI continued work in the area of efficient and
high-quality object rearrangement is inspired by results from Dr. Dan
Halperin's research group. A journal article was published in the
Advanced Robotics journal in 2017 given this effort.

In collaboration with Dr. Jingjin Yu's group from Rutgers University,
the PI has demonstrated optimal and near-optimal solvers for certain
types of rearrangement challenges. This work was presented at the
"Robotics: Science and Systems" conference in 2017 (RSS) and was one
of the three nominated papers for the Best Student Paper award. This
also led in a journal article that appeared at the International
Journal of Robotics Research.

In collaboration with Dan Halperin's group, the research team moved to
the case of two robotic arms collaborating to rearrange multiple
objects in a commonly shared workspace. Efficient approximate methods
were proposed and demonstrated in a paper that appeared at the top
motion planning meeting, the Workshop on the Algorithmic Foundations
of Robotics (WAFR) 2018.

c) The PI also collaborated more recently with Dan Halperin group on
providing a more straightforward analysis of the probabilistic
completeness properties of popular sampling-based motion planners,
such as the RRT algorithm. This analysis brings the promise of a more
effective tool for analyzing the performance of such methods. This
work was presented at the Int. Conference on Robotics and Automation
in 2019.
